questions.question_text: A server administrator recently installed a kernel update to test functionality. Upon reboot, the administrator determined the new kernel was not compatible with certain server hardware and was unable to uninstall the update. Which of the following should the administrator do to mitigate further issues with the newly installed kernel version?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Edit the bootloader configuration file and change the first kernel stanza to reflect the file location for the last known-good kernel files.

This approach allows the server to boot using a previous, stable version of the kernel that is known to be compatible with the server's hardware. By editing the bootloader configuration, the administrator can ensure that the system bypasses the problematic kernel version during the boot process, effectively mitigating the immediate issues caused by the incompatible kernel update. This solution is preferable because it directly addresses the problem without the need for more drastic measures such as a complete OS reinstall or adjusting unrelated security settings like BIOS passwords. Moreover, it preserves the server's configuration and data, avoiding the downtime and work associated with reinstallation.

choices.B: Perform a complete OS reinstall on the server using the same media that was used during the initial install.
choices.D: Set a BIOS password to prevent server technicians from making any changes to the system.
choices.C: Edit the bootloader configuration file and move the newest kernel update stanza to the end of the file.
choices.A: Edit the bootloader configuration file and change the first kernel stanza to reflect the file location for the last known-good kernel files.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Transfer the existing data to an external eSATA enclosure.

choices.A: Copy the existing data to an external USB 3.0 enclosure.
choices.D: Move the existing data to a new, larger internal hard drive.
choices.C: Transfer the existing data to an external eSATA enclosure.
choices.B: Place the existing data on a DVD and use the internal DVD-ROM drive.

questions.question_text: The accounting department needs more storage and wants to retain the current data for quick read-write access. The accounting server does not have any internal drive bays available to keep both disks; however, the server does have USB 3.0 and eSATA ports available. Which of the following is the best way to accomplish the department's goals?

choices.B: Repurpose and recycle any usable server components.
choices.C: Remove all the components from the server.
choices.A: Remove all the data from the server drives using the least destructive method.

discussion.content: This is utterly incorrect. Any competent IT admin would pull/destroy hard drives and memory before donating hardware. Wiping data, even with multiple passes is not sufficient to prevent data recovery.

comments.content: The Answer is D, company policy will explain how to decom your stuff without risking company data.

questions.question_text: An organization is donating its outdated server equipment to a local charity. Which of the following describes what the organization should do before donating the equipment?

An administrator is able to ping the default gateway and internet sites by name from a file server. The file server is not able to ping the print server by name. The administrator is able to ping the file server from the print server by both IP address and computer name. When initiating an nslookup from the file server for the print server, a different IP address is returned. Which of the following is most likely the cause?

discussion.content:
C. The DNS entries for the print server are incorrect.

Here's why:

The file server can ping the default gateway and internet sites by name, indicating that DNS resolution is working for those addresses.
However, the file server cannot ping the print server by name, suggesting a DNS resolution issue specific to the print server's hostname.

choices.C: The DNS entries for the print server are incorrect.
choices.B: The DHCP scope option is income ct.
choices.A: Firewall is blocking the ICMP echo reply.

choices.B: has faulty air conditioning that is awaiting service.
choices.C: is almost ready to take over all operations from the primary site.
choices.A: has basic technical facilities connected to it.
choices.D: is fully operational and continuously providing services.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. is almost ready to take over all operations from the primary site.

Warm sites are disaster recovery solutions that have the necessary telecommunications and IT infrastructure but do not have live data. Equipment, including servers and networking hardware, may be present but not fully configured. Warm sites require a short period to become fully operational, making them a middle ground between the faster recovery times of a hot site (which is fully operational and continuously providing services) and the slower recovery time of a cold site (which has basic facilities but no technology until moved there).

questions.question_text: A site is considered a warm site when it:
